Review: Crimes of the Future

16/07/2022

Cavan Gilbey reviews Cronenberg's latest foray into body horror

Image by IMDb

By Lawrence Mason

Prior to seeing Crimes of the Future my knowledge of Cronenberg was severely limited;. I had been indifferent to the very popular Videodrome but adored his often forgotten virtual reality thriller eXistenZ. So though I was far from what you would call an expert on his filmography, he has always been a director whose influence Iâ€™ve felt across many films, most obviously in his sonâ€™s film Possessor. But the premise of Cronenbergâ€™s latest venture, his notable return to the sci-fi genre after twenty-three years, was fascinating to me. The film positions itself around a world where evolution has accelerated our physiology in parallel with huge developments in biotechnology which can interface directly with the human body. Physical pain has disappeared and as a result surgery has become something of a performance art. This is a premise only Cronenberg could make work as well as it does, with anyone else the wider allegory would have been lost in favour of grotesque effects.

Opening with a harrowing chain of events between a mother and son, the former smothering the latter upon finding him eating a plastic bin and digesting it without issue. The film focuses on the duo of Saul (Viggo Mortensen) and Caprice (Lea Seydoux), who make a living performing live surgery on Saulâ€™s vestigial organs (a result of his â€œaccelerated evolution syndromeâ€). Saul eventually finds himself drawn into a fight between an oppressive government and a group of radicals who plan to evolve themselves so they can survive the ongoing climate disaster. Cronenberg offers us a classic liberal rebels vs tyrannical oppressors narrative, but naturally that isnâ€™t the focus of Crimes of the Future.

Instead the ethics of art itself are brought into direct question. Should art be prioritised over the environment? When does the human body start being a commodity and life? The film offers some talking points, and never answers but certainly challenges the way of thinking about the ways we perceive art. A dance sequence from a mostly nude man covered in skin grafted ears with his eyes and mouth sewn shut stands as a testament to the liberating power of music. The blind and mute dancer has no way of verbally expressing what his art is, as he exists in a world where he has no true personal definition as a result of his surgery. Much like a fleshy Ship of Theseus, his body has been altered so many times that the beauty of his original self is no longer a consideration for those watching. Onlookers describe the show as â€˜sexyâ€™ and â€˜ground breakingâ€™, yet Cronenberg never lets us see the whole performance, deliberately making us â€˜not get itâ€™.

Naturally with this being David Cronenberg, the production design is often vile and makes the skin crawl in the best possible ways. The first thing that we see of this biomechanical aesthetic are chairs and beds which appear to be made of bone, bringing back vivid memories of the organic gun and fleshy games consoles of eXistenZ. The chair is the more unsettling of the two, as it squirms and jolts around to aid Saul in eating and digesting food, often with sickening clicking noises accompanied by the sounds of Mortensen choking. The surgical scenes are wince-inducing; whether that be watching cameras crawl beneath the skin to get glimpses at tattooed organs or the installation of a zipper on Saulâ€™s stomach which is used to achieve cinemaâ€™s most unsettling kiss. There is one sex scene between Saul and Caprice which made me almost turn away completely; I shanâ€™t say anything other than that it proves Cronenberg is still a â€˜cutâ€™ above the rest when it comes to ruining the human body. Bad pun I know, but to describe it in full may fulfil Cronenbergâ€™s promise that this movie will make you want to throw up and leave the room.

Unfortunately some elements didnâ€™t fully work for me;, most notably the way that some characters feel like set-dressing rather than three-dimensional people. Kristen Stewart, who gives an amazingly uncomfortable turn as registry worker Timlin, doesnâ€™t get a chance to really do anything, until a scene in the final act which is over far too quickly for her character gets a chance to develop. There are a couple of government agents who, much like Timlin, get one scene at the end where they do something interesting with a pair of drills. The biggest casualty is Welket BunguÃ©â€™s Detective Cope, who is set up in an interesting way, with his conservative view of art and a cynical outlook regarding vestigial organ growth as the lucky charm the art world sees it. But heâ€™s mostly absent from scenes where he should have been investigating and getting closer to Saul, often feeling like a secondary inclusion just so there could be a character representing the government in order to balance out the evolutionists.

Crimes of the Future is not going to be for everyone, and though it doesnâ€™t seem to be the grand return desired by a swathe of Cronenberg purists, I was engrossed in its bleak post-climate disaster world where everyone felt so tired and art had developed into something that feels almost purely voyeuristic despite the genuinely earnest artistic heart behind it. Body horror will always be a genre I love and Crimes of the Future fills a very specific void that I needed occupied in my sci-fi viewing. The film has a perfect blend of the subtle and sophisticated, with utterly horrifying displays of allegorical surgical violence, however at points, characterisation is ultimately sacrificed to achieve this.Prior to seeing Crimes of the Future my knowledge of Cronenberg was severely limited;. Kristen Stewart, who gives an amazingly uncomfortable turn as registry worker Timlin, doesnâ€™t get a chance to really do anything, until a scene in the final act which is over far too quickly for her character gets a chance to develop. Body horror will always be a genre I love and Crimes of the Future fills a very specific void that I needed occupied in my sci-fi viewing. The film has a perfect blend of the subtle and sophisticated, with utterly horrifying displays of allegorical surgical violence, however at points, characterisation is ultimately sacrificed to achieve this.
